title: Great practice and great respect
body: Today I had a abcess sorted out the care and respect I received was  of the very highest standard from all of the teams that dealt with me the surgery team made me feel at easy and in safe hands. I would recommend Frimley to everyone. My words of thank you just don't seem enough.

title: Great Practice
body: I have had excellent experience at this surgery. I have found reception staff to be very polite and helpful. Moreover, I have nothing but the praise for practising doctors, who are not only professional but approachable and helpful. More recently, I am particularly pleased about regular weekly telephone contact by surgery staff during this ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Excellent service
body: Simple and easy to use registration and online medical problem process. The call back from GP was timely and really helpful, I uploaded a photo of injury for GP to review who then called me back within minutes with further advice. A visit to nurse practitioner was required this was arranged promptly during the call. Visit to practice was efficient and appointment was on-time, the visit felt safe at all times. Overall a brilliant service was provided.

title: Fantastic Practice & Service
body: I always receive a call back from my doctor when required.  This practice runs extremely efficiently and staff are courteous and helpful.

title: Excellent experience
body: My first visit to this hospital. The staff were all extremely friendly, working under Covid19 restrictions. The Consultant was excellent with a superb bedside manner. It is a shame that protocol precludes me from naming the Consultant, but I believe he has a bird of prey thar measures 3ft long. Many thanks, keep up the good work .

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: The best maternity care in the country
body:
Three kids and counting! 

Two I had at DRI 2017&2018, then a home birth December 2019 and these midwives should be cherished. Each one of them, pretty confident I've been seen by most!! They are all incredible humans, kind, compassionate, professional and so warm. Made all three of my births a safe and wonderful place for me and our babies to be born into I cannot thank you all enough for all you’ve done for our family. You’re so appreciated! The kindest Regards to a truly wonderful service. 

Thank you.

readBy.name: Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Thank you so much
body: I attended with my 6 month old son so he could get an EEG, on Wednesday and Thursday this week.  I just wanted to say a huge thank you to the two wonderful ladies that dealt with his care. They were both so incredibly kind and made a huge, positive difference to how I was feeling. I don’t think I could ever explain how much it means to me, but I just wanted to say thank you for being so kind and reassuring. You both helped me feel so much more confident and feeling like I’m doing a good job at being a mum. People can’t see others’ internal struggles but a little kindness and friendliness certainly goes a long way.

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: greenww69
title: Many years of this service
body:
After many years of using this service, I would like to thank all the staff for their support!  
But especially Dave, because of his wisdom and friendly nature, I believe he played a massive part of my recovery.  
Thank you Dave,

title: Midwifes
body:
I went to labor for my first baby. All midwifes were so kind, helping, and caring.
I only remember one of them midwifes re appointment.

title: Quick call-back during lockdown
body: I wrote a short message on the surgery’s website over the weekend, relating to my asthma inhaler prescription. I expected a call early to mid week from a nurse, but instead received a call on Monday morning at 08:41 from a GP. We quickly resolved the issue and I was promised a solution on the spot which meet some my needs. Keep up the good work!

title: Exceptional, efficient practice
body: Within 36 hours I had been registered, contacted to make an appointment and called by a doctor. Prescription ready for collection 2 hours after that and blood tests arranged swiftly for the following week, which we were carried out with excellent COVID safety precautions in place.

title: Really helpful even when using remote…
body: The telephone consultation was good, and the service where you fill in info and provide pictures, then get a detailed report from the doctor in an email was really helpful.  Having a written prognosis to read at your leisure was extremely helpful and comforting.  It came on the same day I filled in the form.  The front and back end staff are really helpful.

title: Thank you nurse
body: Very professional and compassionate person.  Caring women who I have no problem being checked/treated by.  This nurse is kind and humane like how all nurses should be but who unfortunately aren’t thesedays.  Keep up the good work 🌟🌟🌟🌟🌟

title: Great Health Care assistant
body: I attended the surgery this morning for the first time during the covid crisis. The receptionist (at 8.45am) was really friendly and helpful. The HCA (Carly) was kind and professional. She really put me at ease and is obviously very competent at her job. I would just like to say how impressed I was and say thank you.

title: Quality care
body:
I have been using Beacon medical group for appointments since the late 80’s.  Having visited several of the practices in the group, I must say it has always been very welcoming and professional.   With the process changes and the unfortunate current Covid 19 issues
I do find how it works now, getting an appointment is far easier, being able to use a computer/smart phone for this and the Beacon group web site gives so much information to help us all to find an appropriate solution for our health needs.  Urgent care is just such a great option to get treatment the same day if required.  I highly recommend this practice group and many of the sites have a chemist attached to the surgery for collection of your medicines.  All staff I have had any dealings with have always been pleasant and professional.

title: Fantastic Health Care Assistant
body: I had a blood test today. I normally feel faint whilst giving blood. However on this occasion I was made to feel really comfortable and it went really well. Thanks to the health care assistants!

author: blackops1958
title: Attending the AntiCouaglulant Clinic
body:
Nursing staff member being confrontational and rude to me on more than 3 occasions, I asked other staff that work in the same area and was advised this person is always like that. I believe that they began targeting me due to being an NHS employee myself and their comments have been degrading such as calling me a liar in regards to how I manage my warfarin medication.  
I have asked previously to not have this staff member see me and I understand sometimes requests cant be met due to on going circumstances but I don't believe this person is fit for the service and has some serious issues regarding how they treats patients and this is the last time I am going to be made to feel uncomfortable for something that should be over in 5 minutes.

author: Mrs McDonald
title: Specialist midwife service - Grampian
body:
I wish to highly praise & thank the service for the help & support I received following the birth of my baby girl when diagnosed with Postnatal Depression. In particular Shona went above & beyond to help & support me & get me the appropriate care which resulted in my being admitted into the MBU at Livingstone which was also a great & beneficial experience.  
I even went onto have another baby & was thankful once more for Shona’s help & support. I also received great service from Dr Bandyopadhyay Consultant Obstetrician at Aberdeen Maternity Hospital, his care was amazing & he even delivered my baby boy, such a lovely man.  
I have also to praise Dr Cooper physiatrist at Cornhill hospital, he’s so been lovely, efficient & very supportive

readBy.name: Office of Stewart Stevenson, MSP for Banffshire and Buchan Coast

author: Bigbear
title: One of the nicest people on earth
body:
In January I had a upper molar removed and with large upper molars my Sinus floor has suffered a tear.  
In short, along comes Covid and after infection and infection I eventually get to the Glasgow dental hospital with the help of Dr. Sarah  
I've had my Xrays and a scan today and I'm awaiting surgery in a few months for hopefully stitching me up and getting me back to normal.  
I'd just like to say that Dr Sarah was one of the nicest people on earth I've ever met. I'm going through a stressful time in my life as my dad is dying in hospital of a brain tumour and Sarah really did help at this stressful time in my life assuring me that she would help me get my sinus tear sorted.  
I wanted to type this and say that what a wonderful Ray of sunshine she has been and is so attentive and caring. She explains herself professionally and radiates positive energy which is very much appreciated.  
I wish she was my Dentist as I'm sure she is a positive asset to anyone who she comes into contact with. I'd just like to say thankyou to her for being there for me and helping me at this time in my life. I hope the sun always shines on her face and the wind be on her back.  
Furthermore all the other staff on the Glasgow Dental hospital have been so nice and polite and caring.  
Thankyou all for your time and help

author: Listened to
title: I know you are always there for our family
body:
Once again I have to give congratulations to my GP practice, McLean Medical Eastwood Health Centre Glasgow.  
During these most difficult months the service I have received from the person at the end of the phone to the wonderful team of doctors that supported me during the past weeks with severe knee pain, I can't Thank You enough for listening and supporting me.  
I was sent to hospital within 2 weeks of my last appointment and after steroid injection and fluid removed I had a full nights sleep for the first time in months.  
I know you are always there for our family. Thanks for your care and support at all times. It is truly appreciated.

readBy.name: East Renfrewshire Health & Social Care Partnership

title: Excellent care
body: I was admitted to the hospital with severe dehydration after spending a long day in the sun. I was very impressed with the thorough investigation of my symptoms and the excellent care that I received. The staff I met, from administrators to nurses and doctors, were all kind and caring, as well as being very thorough in their investigation of my symptoms. The treatment I received enabled me to be discharged later in the evening. If I have to go to  hospital in the future, I would be confident about returning to the Alexandra Hospital - thank you to all the staff I met.

title: No help
body: My dad had an oppoinment today and he's turned up to be told he carnt be seen when he's got catarax in his eyes I'm totally discusted in yourself if he goes blind I'll be going further as you know his eyes are bad as the options refered him

author: Bereavedbyageism
title: I believe that age discrimination affected my husbands care
body:
I believe that age discrimination in healthcare on Ward A604 at the Bristol Royal Infirmary killed my husband. DNR was put in place, following what felt like bullying of a vulnerable and profoundly deaf patient, against the wishes of both him and his wife.  
Surgery was carried out in the absence of any instruction re: resuscitation, after he, and I, insisted the DNR was struck out of his record. Despite this, I was repeatedly told that no resuscitation or ventilation would be applied. He was not ventilated or moved to ICU, as we had originally been told he would be, and the doctors persisted in saying he wouldn’t be resuscitated or ventilated. An infinitely valuable life was prematurely ended.  
Those of us left traumatised by the callousness and inhumanity of the treatment he, and we, received will never recover.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust

author: john aq
title: my Experience
body: I asked to to speak to a councillor. It was helpful, reassuring and supportive

author: Odd Pyjamas
title: Eye Clinic Waiting time initiative
body:
I have been treated for raised eye pressures and latterly glaucoma for nearly 23 yrs since the age of 39. I have lived in Scotland for 20 years and lived within 4 different Health Boards and fully understand there is a lack of Glaucoma specialists.  
Just over 2 years ago I moved to a different Scottish Health Board. My new GP referred me to the local health board to get in to their system and review. Over the last 2 years I have seen a different Consultant at weekend clinics. These Consultants came from a variety of Health Boards across the UK e.g. London, Carlisle. I was told they were working for the local Glaucoma Consultant and these Saturday clinics were being undertaken to ensure the waiting times were kept down but if any problem was detected I would be seen by the local Glaucoma Specialist.  
After an emergency admission to hospital for another reason my eye drops were reviewed and changed and my GP wrote to the local Glaucoma Specialist to inform him. I was then asked to attend to see the local Glaucoma Specialist as a new patient who had no hospital notes from the locum private Consultants. Tests done that day showed my pressures were very high, there had been further 13% visual loss in the right eye. Furthermore it transpired none of the locum Consultants had taken the issue of my extremely thin cornea in to consideration at their reviews and had not given me any appropriate review of my previous trabulectomy. The local Glaucoma specialist arranged for me to have urgent laser trabuloplasty to try and bring down pressures. I was fortunate this was done as lockdown started but have no idea if it has been successful yet. The Glaucoma Specialist stated these Consultants ‘do not work for him’ and for 2 years I had received sub-optimal treatment which has caused more eye damage.  
If I had not had an emergency hospital admission the issue may still have not been detected and continued visual loss. This weekend initiative may result in the Government waiting times being kept in check but if others patients like me have not received appropriate timely treatment what will the clinical effects be and how will it effect their long term quality of life? In addition there is extra pressure put on the regular NHS Scotland Consultants who have to deal with the mistakes. I cannot imagine paying private agency Consultants being a cheap option. Why is the funding for this initiative be put in to frontline eye clinics of the regular Consultants instead?

author: serpenswq96
title: Calling the out of hours team
body:
Called at 17: 35. Didn't get through as ever, was told to leave a message or phone Rethink/Samiritans. This is immediately a bad start as it indicated my mental was not taken seriously and can be dealt with by non specialists who don't have my medical records to hand and can't really help.  
I don't like phoning the out of hours team as I have had previous issues with lack of service. I've been told by some staff that I have no mental health issues, and by others that I am wasting their time in previous calls. Also I've had the phone put down on me during an episode and yet been told during another call that because I'm calm there's no problem as I'd be angry and emotional if there was. So you can't win with them.  
They've been the subject of complaints but the reply is always 'you were abusive to us'. When this is challenged by my care workers, who point out I was having an episode and they're trained to deal with this no response is given.  
Got no option but to phone them today as no other help is available. It's now 1747 and they haven't phoned back. I'm sorry the episode I've been trying to hold off all day hasn't happened on a weekday. I need someone really quickly to talk me down, I can't hold in the rage much longer, everything is prickly heat right now and throwing stuff against he wall only wards it off for a few minutes.  
1802 Staff member phoned up. I explained how I've been holding in the rage all day and that I needed someone to talk me down. They said they weren't able to get anyone out to see me (Odd really, as I've seen 2 members of staff out at 1am to deal with someone who put a window through near the Cathedral a while back, but that's not like me, who they can pass on to someone else so there you go)  
The staff member suggested I go for a walk. I pointed out that I'm trying to hold in a rage here and didn't really want to leave the house in case I had a confrontation. They then suggested I punch a pillow to take away the rage. I said I need to hear something break. They then seemed to take offence at me refusing their ideas and said this is not going to help, saying I had gone in here with an idea of what should be done (Imagine that! ) and they can't send anyone out because they haven't got the resources. I pointed out that's not true and recounted the meeting above, suggested this was won't as opposed to can't. 'welllll' and then I said 'that makes two of us' and put the phone down.  
At no point did I raise my voice, swear or insult the staff member, I merely pointed out the treatment I've had in the past and, despite more £££ allegedly being put in there it's still the same story, I don't get help from the out-of-hours team as I don't have drug or alcohol issues.  
They are simply discouraging me from phoning them again.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: intensitycf39
title: A very pleasant experience
body: In essence my experience today has been excellent... the Ward was easy to find as it was well labelled. The staff have been very friendly, meeting me at the seated area I was in and escorting me to my station. Each "Station" (chair etc. ) is adequately spaced out between the contrasting so that there is enough space to manoeuvre (I. e. for bathroom trips etc. ) My drug was up and running on time quickly and efficiently. In conclusion a very pleasant experience

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: woodpigeonec96
title: Transfusion Day Care
body:
I live in the Luyan area. From September 2019 I attended the Dill in Craigavon Hospital until it was relocated due to the virus. I was getting a blood transfusion most weeks. When Craigavon closed I was transferred to DCC at South Tyrone.  
I find it difficult to put into words the wonderful care and atmosphere there is here in South Tyrone. The whole area is much brighter. There is a better access to staff if you require any help. The ward itself is bright and cheerful - much better than the surroundings at C.A.H. I do hope the unit continues to operate here from South Tyrone where I can honestly say the care is of the very highest standards.  
Thank you to all the staff for their professional help.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: cassiopeiary44
title: IBD Biologic
body: Attended South Tyrone to receive my biologic treatment and the service and set up is very good. Nursing staff very helpful and friendly. The set up at South Tyrone compared to previously in CAH I personally think it better as the ward is bigger, more space and comfort. In all the services is good at both locations.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: charliete47
title: An enjoyable experience overall
body: I have colitis and therefore need to receive treatment so that it stays under control. I had and appointment for 2pm at the South Tyrone Hospital in Dungannon. I was able to find a parking space ok and I entered the front of the hospital and was then able to follow the signs that led me to the Day Clinical Centre where I receive my treatment. I was greeted when I arrived and was seen shortly after by a nurse who took my temperature and then directed me towards a sink so that I could wash my hands and then put on a face mask. Once I had on the mask I was shown to where I would receive my treatment and I was weighed, blood pressure checked, pulse and temperature taken. After this I had to get on IV in done in a relatively good time without much hassle and was an enjoyable experience overall. The staff/nurses are all very nice and make you feel welcomed at ease for getting your treatment and I can say that everyone should have an enjoyable experience.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: magpiejs64
title: IV Biologics
body:
-Seen to promptly on arrival  
-Provided with facemask, temp taken and asked to wash hands. Reassuring to know all precautions being taken with Regard to Covid-19  
-Provided with Sealed water bottle again happy to have this instead of water jug and cup at the moment  
-All nurses as usual very attentive and pleasant  
-On a whole very positive experience with no issues

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: memberdc65
title: A great experience
body:
I have had a great experience.  
At all times was always treated with respect and great care at both Craigavon and Dungannon. Many thanks to all the staff, Doctors and nurses for a great Job. Thank you very much.  
Special thanks to Margret

title: Great practice
body:
I had a blood test done, the reports were made available online and the doctor responded to all my queries promptly.

I also requested repeat prescription online which was sent quickly to the pharmacy as well.

Thanks

author: F Brin
title: Issues with the new appointment system
body:
The care and medical advice provided by the doctors at this practice is good however I don't feel the same about reception.  
There is an issue with the way the new appointments system has been introduced with no warning or literature to patients, and the way that this has led to reception staff treating people badly.  
I have attempted to use the new eConsult system many times to try and get an appointment and each time it has told me to contact '111'. The only way to get anywhere is to lie and put incorrect information in. Do I need to go through the ordeal of answering over 20 questions when I just want an appointment? If no question is relevant to my issue and it tells me that something is an emergency when it isn't, I don't think it can be considered fit for purpose. I also object to having to detail my private information in this way.  
When I've called reception for help, I'm told that I must be doing it wrong and that there is no other way for me to book an appointment. I've pleaded with them to book me a telephone consultation and they have refused. I'm told that because I sound young and because I have an email address that I must be able to use the eConsult system. This is complete nonsense, how can you assume something by someone's voice when you don't know anything about them. I have friends and family in their forties who aren't technically savvy and wouldn't be able to use this system.  
Something as straightforward as phoning to book an appointment has become a complete ordeal, this is now the 3rd time I have been refused one. Why am I being turned away when I am asking to see a Doctor? It is a perfectly reasonable request to ask for an appointment over the telephone.  
Further to this I'm told I'm not able to see my preferred GP. I can only see the person that they/the system deems suitable for me. It should be the patient's choice how they want to book to see their GP and now neither eConsult or a receptionist will do this for you. Personally I don't mind waiting longer for a non-urgent appointment with my chosen doctor, but this is no longer an option. Why has booking appointments online been completely disabled? This is yet another option that has been taken away. All the confidence I had in knowing that I could get an appointment easily and being able to see the Doctor I want has completely evaporated.  
I understand the need to modernise services, however, we should have been consulted in advance about this change and it not be just enforced on us. The customer needs time to adjust in a gradual process. Human support and a range of options for booking appointments still needs to be available for patients, and the staff should be far more accommodating in the process, not refusing to make people appointments.  
Please review how you are doing things and how it makes the patient feel. I have been seriously upset and stressed out by this series of events and if this unaccommodating 'cant do' attitude persists I will have to move to another surgery.

author: Sioban
title: Midwifery Care
body:
Kelly is a passionate, caring, supportive and genuine midwife who goes above and beyond for her patient. My experience of being pregnant would have been completely different if it hadn’t been for the kindness shown by Kelly.  
I suffer with anxiety and through my pregnancy this became extreme. I took myself to see Kelly at 24 weeks pregnant and was nervous about speaking up as so often anxiety is seen as just “worrying”. I was terrified I would be seen as dramatic or it be put down as “just something that happened on pregnancy”. However, on speaking to Kelly she instantly made me feel like I was doing the right thing by speaking up, she listened, genuinely listened and completely understood what I was feeling. She suggested that I see her every week for a check up to try and help reassure me that the precious little one in my tummy was ok.  
I felt a genuine connection with her and completely trusted her judgement. She cares for her patients more than any other healthcare professional that I have ever come in to contact with and Kelly is without a doubt, a total credit to the NHS and without her support I don’t think I could have came through my pregnancy so well. She made sure to come and see me when I was discharged from hospital to do my checks and make sure me and baby were ok. Lockdown happened towards the end of my pregnancy and that came as a shock to everyone but Kelly made sure to still call me every week. She is a star, and I can’t speak highly enough of her as a professional, and as an individual.

author: jadeward186
title: poem from a Jade ward patient / Covid lockdown
body:
Lock Down.
Frightened, Scared.
Not being able to see my family and heroes on other wards.
DRC T. I’s are great always willing to help.
Apprehensive! ! About COVID 19. Of catching the awful bug.
Enjoyed gardening.
Great to hear loved ones on the phone.
Having hair done made me feel good in myself.
Visits beginning soon. Can’t wait to see my mum and dad with a warm loving smile.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: dancezw77
title: #Rampton Supports Covid
body:
On our ward, we have been embracing our artistic creativity. We have been colouring in and cutting our a butterfly to represent every covid death. People from all over the hospital and beyond have took part colouring and cutting. Both staff and patients have been doing artwork on the corridor walls to decorate and make the ward look better. It's been fun and enjoyable and brought the patients and the staff who support it closer together.  
Thanks to everyone who helped out and appreciated the hard work we've been doing.  
#RamptonSupportsCovid

author: leopardth53
title: A really positive atmosphere on this ward
body:
I came on to C Block 8 months ago and have found it to be the best ward in the Hospital. The Staff are really nice and approachable, my peers are all settled and overall theres a really positive atmosphere on this ward theres no bickering or any negative behaviours.  
The staff are easy to talk to and they also promote to be self reliant which gives the patient extra responsibility like I said I've been here for 8 months and have now gained around so thank you to all the staff and peers

title: Disorganised and rude
body:
Was told to wait in my car until nurse comes to collect my mother in law, rang to let them know we were there 40 min rang again. Nurse told me she had been there the whole time, she hadn't. So basically calling me a liar. My daughter called reception to complain who were dismissive and rude  who said I was lying she saw what happened. I don't think so. 
I am going to change my mother in law to another practice.

author: samand ted
title: my alcohol addiction
body: people ask me when I first noticed my addiction problem, but after a lot of research into my own past, I think I would say "after my first drink", the fact that it reduced anxiety, gave me false confidence, and improved my wellbeing, so if any addict will tell you, "if it makes you feel good, take it more, and more", what I didn't realise at the time(through no education-by the way this was the mid-seventies) is that at the beginning "it works" but as you increase your tolerance, you need to drink, more, and more-that's when things turn sour-the alcohol is a depressant, you start to encounter problems externally and internally-you have financial, employment physical injuries, hangovers, sickness-mental problems increase-anxiety, depression, concentration, it as if it has metamorphosed into something else, you don't get any "fun" anymore-but by then you're "hooked", -it is only by being recommended by my GP that CGL has turned my life around.

title: Webinar event
body: Patients were notified of a webinar conducted by doctors on the subject "Coronavirus in Leicester: what you need to know". I registered for the event, received the link and tried to join at 7pm....by 7.15 I gave up. The link did not work and tho an older person am very computer literate.  Apart from the disappointment of maybe learning something I did not know - I would respectfully  suggest that whatever knowledge this event would impart, it is about two months too late. I have a slight lung condition and was midst an appointment with the respiratory clinic but of course the was cancelled. However, I was contacted by the Consultant. As this was a recurrence he would normally ask for an Xray, followed by a C.T if the former did not show clearly what the problem was.  He told me to take care and hoped that the lockdown would not last too long.  Although not on the Government list, I have tried to follow all the rules and have taken extra care, and so the Webinar may have given me some important information.  It was not to be

title: Expert Care
body:
I rang the surgery at 8.30am and was told I was first in a queue. I waited less than ten seconds before speaking to a receptionist who was pleasant, business-like and who inspired confidence.I asked to speak to a named doctor using the triage service. Within twenty minutes the doctor rang me and, having listened to my concerns, organised appropriate investigation of my symptoms, including blood tests at the surgery and a scan at a nearby hospital. 
She was very professional and friendly. She asked appropriate questions and explained what action she would instigate and why. Several times she reminded me that the services the practice provides are available to me and I should not hesitate to contact the surgery again should I feel the need. 
The entire conversation was conducted in a brisk but unhurried manner, and I felt no pressure to be as quick as possible. It was completed in just over five minutes. 
I felt reassured and confident that matters would be addressed efficiently and effectively. 
I have complete trust in the surgery and its staff.

title: Very upset
body: Every time I try to call and book a appointment the receptionist will say there is no appointments available (I am Italian and my english is very good). I always have to ask my british friend to call, otherwise the receptionist will not even book me in for a appointment. It is very upsetting as the doctors are really nice, it is just a challange to get to them. I have been with this GP for over 2 years and have been experiencing this every time

title: I was scared
body: I was an emergency admission to Worthing Hospital in April this year  and terrified of the corona virus in hospitals.  From the moment I was admitted via A&E and then the emergency admissions ward I was amazed at the organisation implemented to protect patients. Brilliant planning, organisation implementation and clinical practices.  Well done and a very big THANK YOU to Everyone.

readBy.name: Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Expert care and support
body: I can’t thank all the nurses and doctors in the intensive care unit for looking after me whilst I was extremely ill with severe asthma. I received round the clock care with such dedication and support. A big thank you to you all xx

title: Wonderful mother-and-baby 8-week checks
body: Very positive experience at my second daughter's 8-week postnatal checks. Superb interaction with receptionists doing a wonderful job in the face of coronavirus, and really positive experience with highly-engaged doctor.

title: Lovely caring practice
body: Helpful friendly staff and doctors. Always try to offer appointments where they can. Receptionists kind, polite and friendly. Happy to be a patient at this surgery.

title: Fantastic Cardiology
body:
Thank you everyone on Ward 24A from the cleaners, helpers, nurses and doctors. You are all so amazing, professional and caring. Even the hospital food was outstanding. Thank you chefs and all who prepare cook and serve. You are all a great credit to an NHS which is so often maligned. Thank you so much. With the kindest of regards.
John Johnstone

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Concerned re post covid19 Experience Econsult.
body: I have always had good care from this practice but post covid19 and the practice stopping face to face appointments and them being triaged via econsult I have some concerns after my experience of this. I am on a medication and have had side affects. In the past the Dr told me to contact them if I had these side affects . I did this via the  Econsultation form. ( by the way the practice website is now just hideously bad in terms of usability ) it is so busy with so many different types of contact here and there that I expect many find it hard to navigate now. I filled my form in and waited for a response I got a phone call that I missed and a voice message left. I phoned back within a couple of hours and was told the person dealing with this was busy but would call me back. They didn’t call back then after another few hours so I called again. Slightly abrupt receptionist said I was on their list for a call back. No call has come. I filled this form in on Tuesday the 7 th and it is now 3 days and I haven’t had a response to my initial concerns. I have access to my notes and saw online that an annotation that a  failed contact and message left on answer phone  was added To my notes but no notes re me calling back 2 times to chase this up. This concerns me greatly as if I did have a problem from not being contacted it would look like I failed to chase this up which I have attempted to do so. All contacts from me to the surgery should be noted on my patient record and if this hasn’t happened it is deeply concerning. So what can I do? I have filled in the form I have chased up after the first missed phone call I can’t really do anything else so I am in limbo. I am ok with technology and cogent of the need to chase a response up but I expect there are many patients at the practice who are not. Covid19 is an unprecedented health crisis but I think that this model of change to a complete  No face to face appointments unless triaged is not really acceptable or it seems not to have worked for me anyway. As a patient I feel disenfranchised of the ability to have the care that best suites me. I hope the practice returns to a more normal model of patient care soon but I doubt this will  happen. I might just be unlucky and perhaps this is working for the majority but for me I don’t like this but I have zero options as this seems to be the only way to access primary health care at present. My main concern though is how 2 contacts from me to the practice have not been recorded in my clinical notes this should never happen and is very worrying form a professionalism view. Notes should always be contemporaneous and yet this don’t happen twice. This needs addressing as a matter of urgency by the practice manager.

title: Outstanding practice
body: My family and I have been patients at the Vale practice for many years and the quality of care is outstanding. The system they have for booking appointments works very well, with same day apts for those that need them. Staff really care about their patients, following up after consultations when necessary. I highly recommend this practice.

author: Mrs T 1410
title: Named Midwife during lockdown
body:
After falling pregnant at the end of last year (2019) I was placed in a pilot study for a named midwife in community. I live in Barrhead and gave birth in the RAH Paisley. My named midwife was Holly. I cannot praise her enough. Having one person to liaise with throughout my pregnancy definitely reduced my anxiety. Giving birth in a pandemic, not being able to have my husband at the appointments and losing my Gran at the beginning of April, made my pregnancy difficult mentally.  
Holly never failed to reassure me and answer all questions. Not having to repeat my story to different people at every appointment helped me open up more and made the whole experience a better one at such a difficult time. I hope the named midwife scheme continues after lockdown and they expand it all over Scotland as it is such a wonderful thing.  
The midwives in the RAH labour suite (Debbi, Hayley and Laura) and the ward were also amazing at what was a difficult time. The medical staff, Costas and Dr P were also brilliant. I was admitted in June.

title: Fantastic Treatment
body:
During treatment of radiotherapy-after a cancer operation-it was noted my heart beat was 30 bpm instead of 60-70 btm.I was immediately transferred to John Radcliffe and less than 24 hours later had a pacemaker fitted. My radiotherapy could then continue.What service!!!
I would also highly praise the Churchill Hospital for their sensitive and caring in a traumatic time for a cancer patient.

author: BoPeep
title: Lost hospital appointment letter
body:
My GP told me I had an ENT consultant appointment tomorrow but did not know the details.
I wanted to know the time and location of the appointment and whether it was face to face or telephone, before traveling to the hospital.
I guessed the wrong hospital and they were curt in saying they had no record of me and couldn’t help.
I felt frustrated as I didn’t know why they had no record. I called back to the Lawson practice and Shazia was able to look up my record and tell me the correct hospital. She also gave me details of the appointment and the phone number of the hospital. She listened well to my problem and was supportive and professional. I felt I could have phoned again and would be helped if I needed to. I spoke to three people in reception in different hospitals/clinics that day and the Lawson Practice reception stood out in their politeness and helpfulness. They were willing to go the extra mile despite being busy.

title: Poor customer service
body:
Completely understanding of the current situation with COVID-19, however, today I experienced the poorest customer service from a member of the admin/reception team. I asked for a call back from the Dr as my 18 month old baby is very unwell and distressed. They assured me I’d get a call back asap, I had my phone next to me, the whole time waiting for this call. Hours later I receive a call from admin to advise the dr couldn’t get through to me and now I’ll have to wait until later for a call back. I pleaded for a different doctor to phone as my child is clearly unwell and distressed. I was rudely interrupted and told to “hang on while she talks” and persisted to tell me there was nothing else she could do. And I was advised to take my child to A&E!! I’ve previously worked in the NHS for 5 years, in a GP practice. And that is not the advise I would have given to a parent with a young child in the middle of a pandemic.  
I can assure you there was NO phone calls from a GP so now my child has to wait even longer for GP advice. If this was for me, I would not be phased by waiting longer, but when it’s my baby - I struggle to see how this is acceptable.

title: Herm Ward
body: My wife was cared for in Herm ward for 9 months and at times presented with challenging behavior, at all times the patience and caring of all staff was evident and she was treated with compassion and care. All the staff took tine to know my wife and what would help when she became distressed,it was reassuring to know she was in safe hands. Staff also took time to know the family members and make us welcome and informed when we visited. All the staff really do go above and beyond in providing an excellent level of care and reassurance to all patients and are a credit to the NHS.

readBy.name: Dorset HealthCare University NHS Foundation Trust

title: PLEASE SORT THIS OUT
body: My wife got blood test paperwork through the post at the beginning of this month, it showed appt only at certain venues and walk in service at Cheshunt Community Hospital. We went there today only to find out that it has been appt only since March. Can you please update your paperwork as many people only go once a year as a result of medicine reviews, creating a waste of fuel, money and time.

title: good practice
body: the only thing wrong is trying to get though for an appointment on the same day or that week. it's always 2 or 3 weeks later.  when you need to see someone urgently.

title: A caring practice
body: This is a kind and caring practice, where all the staff always try their best to help.  Appointments are never rushed and you feel like you are given the time and care you need. An example of the NHS at its best. Thankyou for caring.

title: Terrible
body: Not a nice place to phone,i really dread it when I need to see a doctor..the people that answer the phone are not very nice at all and I don't think I should have to discuss the nature of my problem with them,they are not doctors....

title: First class
body: On 6th July after ringing 111 went tom NSECH Ambulatory care thinking they were going to say (time waster). They were so professional,quick blood test then just minutes after an ECG I was blue lighted to Freeman Cardiology where within 20 mins a stent was fitted in a blocked artery in my heart.Thanks to their quick action in NSECH I am now home and feeling great.A heartfelt thanks to the staff at Ambulatory care NSECH

title: Really efficient service
body: Having suspected a viral infection ,I contacted my GP surgery .They requested photos and arranged to call me back in a short time .I spoke to the doctor and a prescription was sent straight to my chemist !! It couldn’t have been more efficient .Great service .

title: Urgent care department
body: The care I received from every single member of staff was outstanding, professional & above all caring & compassionate. One particular nurse who saw me re-entering the department later in the day rushed over concerned & stayed with me. I was given excellent treatment & care. Unfortunately I am unable to name them on this forum due to privacy laws but I am hopeful they will recognise who they are. They are a credit to the profession. From the lovely warm receptionist through the amazing nurses to the doctors outstanding care was in abundance. Thank you very much.

title: Fantastically supportive
body: I just felt I wanted to say how amazing Beaconsfield  have been. I’ve had suspected coronavirus for 3 months and lots of complications and issues. I’ve had many phone appointments with different GPs from the surgery and the majority of them have been amazingly supportive and helpful during a very difficult time. I have never felt dismissed and I’ve always been taken seriously. I can’t fault them and would highly recommend them to anyone.

title: Professional and thorough
body: I went to Sunny Meed Surgery with two worrying symptoms. The practitioner that saw me was welcoming, professional and patient. He undertook various tests and clearly explained what he was doing - he allowed me to ask questions throughout and was thorough in the answers he provided. He set out the next steps of my proposed treatment clearly and provided me with additional information to ensure I understood all aspects. I would have no hesitation in recommending both the practitioner and practice to family and friends.

author: snebber
title: Suspected stroke
body:
It was Sunday. Woke up feeling dizzy so went to the toilet and felt really sick. Wasnt till later on about 2. 00 really started feeling dizzy very sick and sweating like mad. wife was not happy seeing this she phoned an ambulance.  
The paramedics came right away. They were absolutely brilliant could not have done anymore. Having to do all this while im over a toilet seat is not easy believe me. So out to xhouse hospital Kilmarnock.  
Was assessed taken up to the stroke ward. As soon as I got there I was treated as if I was the king. Absolutely amazing staff could not do enough for me attending to everything to make me more comfortable. So Sunday night wasn't great still same symptoms. Then into the Monday feeling lousy I heard this voice talking to the other patients. And I listened what I heard was the funniest things. This nurse was Alex brilliant heard him singing he was one amazing guy.  
Then I was attended to by John he was one amazing nurse so my problems put my wife at ease on the phone and gave me the medicine that I so badly needed. John virtually never left my side cant thank you enough John. After that met the doctor who was great still being a bit under the weather.  
Tuesday was when I really started feeling better nurses everywhere attending to your every need. Cannot thank them enough every single one of them. Would be unfair to name them all but so good to me. Then I had physio from Ryan which really helped gem of a guy. So Wed I was up for an Mri scan which I am truly blessed came back all clear.  
Although I did feel very sorry for patients in my ward who had all suffered a stroke. So it was the young Doctor who came and told me it was clear and I could go to discharge lounge and get home. So from the bottom of my heart And toall at 3Exhouse hospital you are all brilliant love you all.

title: Horrible rude reception staff
body: I wanted to register as a new patient so I checked their website which said you must register in person and bring proof of ID. So I took my ID there to register and rang the intercom and told them I wanted to register as a new patient. They very rudely and abruptly told me to go away and said that I needed to follow the instructions on the website to register. I told them that on their website it says the opposite and they told me I was wrong and it's all on the website and hung up on me. I opened the website on my phone and rang the buzzer again and read it out to them. It seemed like the person had no knowledge of what was actually on the website and eventually they came outside to hand me some registration forms and told me to post them later. I asked the receptionist how I would show them my ID and they couldn't give an answer, they just told me to go home and call them. So it was a wasted trip and I still don't know how to register, I'll have to call them and hope to speak to someone who actually knows what they are doing and I hope they will actually have some basic manners this time. I've never met such a rude receptionist in my life.

title: poor communications
body: Having to wait weeks for a GP appointment is wrong as 75% of the Latham House GP's only work part time. Not being able to book a on line telephone appointment with your GP is bad. The booking software can be easily modifies to do this.

author: plutojf34
title: Their great care it made her relaxed & comfortable
body: My daughter came to you with a dog bite that had got infected, . Due to this she had to go under general anaesthetic & have the dead skin removed & it washed out, I would just like to thank her surgeons for all there hard work. I would also like to thank all the staff on Kings B Ward for looking after her. It was her first stay in hospital & because of their great care it made her experience relaxed & comfortable. Thanks again.

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Does Anyone Ever Answer the Phone?
body: Phoned and phoned to get blood test results. "You are number one in the queue" but no matter how long I waited it never changed. Tried again the next day with exactly the same result. Useless.

author: Mclane
title: Partners Mum
body:
My partner's mum has been ill for some time, but like any mother didn’t want to show it. It was Easter Sunday 2019, my partner had just picked her mum of from Hospital, she went in on Good Friday, as she hadn’t been feeling too good and with a history of two heart attacks it was for the best.  
We had just come back from a short break in the Lake District, And my other half was excited to be picking her mum up and telling her all about it.  
She picked her mum up and dropped her home, spent an hour or so with her to make sure she was comfortable and that her dad was ok. Checking they had got essentials for a few days so they could manage and we could do a shop for them later in the week. When my other half returned home, we ordered a take away and enjoyed the last dregs of the sun in our garden.  
Later that night, my other half phone rang. It would be a call that would change our lives forever, we were about to spend the most traumatic 4 weeks imaginable for us. There was to be no happy ending.  
I could hear the panic in both my other half and her dads voice, this was not good. She told me what her dad said and she left. 10 minutes later she rang in tears sobbing, I said I’m on my way and set off.  
The journey takes about 20 minutes, it felt longer, taking no notice of anything but just a focus to get there. I pulled up outside the house, there were 2 paramedics crews , my heart sank.  
My partner's mum had collapsed in the bathroom, fallen against the door effectively locking herself in. Her husband who is not very able had been to his shed a good 30 meter distance from the house and had crow-barred the door off. The paramedics team we’re trying their best to establish what was going on. We felt helpless, what had happened, how, 4 hours ago she was laughing and joking, planning a roast dinner and looking forward to our next visit.  
We were asked questions about medical issues , lifestyle and general health and wellbeing.  
Whilst we just wandered aimlessly round the house.  
We were lost upset and just wanted her to be ok.  
An hour or so later, they made the decision to take her away to hospital, the nearest was 10 minutes not the first choice but as the paramedics said, every second is vital, and within minutes she was taken down the stairs in a stretcher into the back of the waiting ambulance.  
We waited and waited, the ambulance didn’t move just stood lights and engine on. What’s going on , what’s happening this isn’t good. It felt an age, then they went full sirens, we gave chase.  
The journey we sat in silence, with our own dark dark thoughts, passing the busy nightlife of the town, how could they possibly enjoying them selves , I felt angry.  
We arrived at the hospital, made our way to A n E , the receptionist had a look of “I’m sorry for you” on her face as we went to the waiting area. And so began a night of sheer anguish, emotional strain and frustration.  
We sat and waited, drank tea, drank water, drank more tea, walked outside.  
This only happens in films I thought, not to us.  
It does happen it’s very very real.  
We found out what was going on in the early hours of the morning.  
A staff nurse had stayed by her side, letting us have a quick visit to the cubicle, he was passionate and reassuring, it’s what we wanted to hear. My partner's mum was almost in some activated nightmare, lashing about unable to control her left side, however her right side remained motionless.  
It was a stroke.  
We got word a surgeon from another hospital had been called, he would be there within the hour, something he was a specialist in, we had hope, I imagined him with a police escort being driven by a chauffeur, just like a film.  
He came, he tried , he couldn’t do what he wanted, she would have to be with some considerable risk moved to another hospital.  
We were told to go home and wait for a call. It was now around 6.30 am.  
We got in, the house was cold, there was the odd piece of used medical equipment wrapping in the hall on the stairs. What do we do now?  
We put the bathroom door on, tried to keep busy. Charged our phones and waited and waited.  
We rang at 11. She had made it and was “comfortable “. Music to our ears. We could go over and visit.  
We were shown to an ICU ward, My partner's mum was in a gown with like an oven mitt on, to protect her arm as she had been flailing it about. My other half rushed to her and undid the Velcro protecting her fingers and gripped her hand , I well up now just thinking about it. It was difficult. She couldn’t speak or communicate, just stare and try to want to get out of the bed. She couldn’t.  
She was poorly, very poorly, she had a stroke and heart attack, and her heart had been torn damage was irreparable.  
And so then for the next four weeks, we lived on a knife edge, day after day we would get a call, “we think you need to get here now, her condition has got worse “. Each time, we expect the worse, by the time we get there she had stabilised, we wait an hour , sometimes two sometimes 4 until we are content to leave her. This process happens almost every other day for over 3 weeks. Our lives are shot, my other half is signed off work to look after her dad and visit the hospital.  
One Sunday we get a call. The weather was sunny, it was now May, we were in limbo.  
We make our way to the hospital, the consultants want to see us. They can do nothing more, they have tried , but she is losing the fight a combination of machine and medicine are keeping her alive.  
My partner said , what must mum be thinking, this was no way to live. They went to see her, held her hand and gave her a kiss, she looked well , Colour in her cheeks her hair brushed, a glint in her eye, but no smile, a look of confusion and frustration in her face.  
We will make her as comfortable as we can the consultant said, Ok, you know best.  
We left, confused, is that it? We waited for a call , it didn’t come that night, my other half and her dad went to the hospital again, she was the same, they spent a few hours, came home.  
Maybe the consultant was wrong? She looked better , no rasping cough, calmer less clammy, still on oxygen but more relaxed looking. We will go again Tuesday, so they did, same , she looked as well as could be expected. We had tea and went to bed.  
23.51 the phone rings. It was my other half’s dad, we had been living these calls for weeks, but this was differs. We drove to his house and he drove us to the hospital. The corridors were silent, mixed with the smell of cleaning fluid and cooked food.  
We made our way to the ward, after picking up a wheelchair for her dad, into the lift, all in silence.  
We pressed the ward buzzer, we were greeted by a familiar nurse.  
“I’m so sorry, Jayne passed away 10 minutes ago, I held her hand I didn’t want her to be alone “  
To us, that’s all we needed. She wasn’t alone and for that we are eternally grateful.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Problem
body: On the 7th July 2020 we submitted 2 requests via the request phone line for repeat prescriptions. On the 10th July on contacting the chemist we were told that the prescriptions had not been received. On contacting the practice we were told that the requests had not been received. Something amiss here.

author: shad
title: Alcohol Detox
body:
When I apply for a home detox with CGL, I did not know what to expect, Then I was introduce to a person called John , who informed me that he was the detox coordinator who would be supporting me through my home detox, I was very nervous appraises and excited to be in this position to start it, My first couple of days I was very sleepy and cant remember much, then on day 3 I started to feel a bit better and healthy and the sickness had stop, my incentive was to carry on and be in a new mind set to start my new life,  
My long term goal is to see my daughter again, I would like to thank CGL for all their support from Roger and John.

title: Good Experience With Online Consultation Service
body: Went online to book a consultation with regard to a tick bite. Found the system to be straightforward and could even upload photographs to give the GP some visual information. Received a call from one of the GPS that same day which represents a very quick turn-round compared to booking an appointment for attendance at the surgery. Got the advice I needed without the need to attend the surgery which is great for both the practice and for me as I'm not taking up so much valuable GP time and I don't risk possible exposure to COVID-19. I can highly recommend the online/telephone consultation system employed by Beacon Medical.

author: Lmcn
title: Thank you from the bottom of our hearts!
body:
We wanted to reach out and leave a message for our amazing labour midwife - Ellen. Having arrived at hospital on my own (due to covid) I was very nervous about going to the delivery room, however, I felt instantly calm and knew I was in good hands when Ellen introduced herself.  
Ellen kept both my husband and I really well informed throughout every single step of the labour and she also managed to keep our minds preoccupied for hours on end asking us about our life story.  
We can’t fault any of the midwives who came in to help during our labour, Ellen, Claire, Stacey and Kirsty the doctor, there were others but we never got all the names! You were all so kind and helpful and made our experience one to remember in a good way.  
We are so grateful for all the encouragement and advice we received and of course all the help to get our beautiful little girl safely into the world. I hope this message finds you and makes you realise what an amazing job you are doing. Thank you from the bottom of our hearts!

readBy.name: Office of John Mason, MSP for Glasgow Shettleston

title: Great doctor, mostly great reception
body: Suffering from depression in a state i rang the practice for help as the dr here is such a wonderful caring man dr was not in and was told to ring back monday i requested to talk to a nurse as my depresion is severe and told no ring back monday to then the receptionist asked about my tablets i dont think this was correct your putting a person with depression and anxiety on the spot my medication is between me and my dr no one else you are not a dr and telling someone who is crying in a depressive state to phone back monday (i rang friday) is incorrect what if i had suicidal thoughts? That would be on you. As i said i cant fault dr hes wonderful reception needs some training

author: Mrs McC
title: Care of my mother
body: My mother fell when walking yesterday.   She lost consciousness and some passers by phoned the ambulance.   The ambulance team got in touch with my father and returned my call when I ran my mum's number.   Stephen, the paramedic was very reassuring.   My mother was admitted to the Emergency Department of the Royal Victoria Hospital, Belfast.   The team took great care of her and I was very grateful to be able to see her for a few minutes.   I was able to leave knowing that she was in safe hands.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

title: Very satisfied
body: Had a telephone consultation with my doctor in regard to my blood pressure. Doctor listen to my concerns and discussed the way forward. At end of consultation I fully understood what my doctor wanted me to do and the medicine he had prescribed. Coul not have wished for better. Did not want to visit surgery because of Covid 19.

title: Prescription
body: Not so much an experience more a question. When do I need to order my repeat prescription to make sure I am not left without my medication. Would it be best if the day I picked up the medication I put in for the next one, which would save my son running about for two or three days a month trying to get my repeat prescription. I am today without my depression tablets again and my son is at this minute running between the surgery and the chemist trying to get hold of a prescription. If he doesn't get the prescription today then it will be Monday trying to chase it up again. I do understand that people are very busy but I do need to collect the prescription before I run out.

title: Poor
body: For the second time in a row I have been issued with a prescription that no pharmacy can fulfill due to manufacturing issues.  Why????  I have now been to several pharmacies and eventually called the surgery.  Who referred me back to the pharmacy.  Who then tried to refer me back to the surgery.  I now have no medication and have to wait until someone makes sense of this farce.  I thought the idea was to reduce contact !!  However I have been all over town and appear to have to go back to where I started if and when  someone rings me with an update.  So much for limiting access.  Asda seem to be more.organised than the medical practice

title: Abandoned
body:
Being a health care practitioner myself (Midwife), I am fully aware of the necessity to cancel and postpone elective surgeries, for the safety of all involved.  But with bariatric surgery, there is a considerable amount of care that goes on around the service.  

The majority of us have given our all to get to the point of surgery and remain eligible.  For some of us it has meant a very challenging time trying to lose a considerable amount of weight (not easy, or we wouldn't be having major surgery to facilitate us!). Since Covid, there has been absolutely no correspondence or support from this service at all.  From the online support groups chat, no one is receiving ongoing anything.  Most of us have put significant weight back on - as our other support services, such as slimming world and weight watchers have also been absent.  

There really isn't any excuse for not reaching out occasionally to those close to surgery to provide some ongoing support and reassurance. As a group of individuals, we would like to know what happens now?  Any kind of communication, written or otherwise would be helpful at this point please.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: What a fantastic minor surgical service -…
body:
The non-scalpel vasectomy service at Latham House Medical Practice is fantastic. My GP referred me to the service at my request, I had heard only good things about it, I was not disappointed. I had to change the date once and the administration team could not have done more to help, then the date was rightly cancelled for COVID19 reasons, but you rearranged as soon as you could. Fantastic administration and impressive attention to detail. The online questionnaire for pre-surgical screening came through on my phone the day before, and was simple to use. 
On the day the surgical team were fantastic. Calm, professional and reassuring. I had a private room to get changed in and have things explained. The surgeon is just brilliant. What a professional service. Well done all.

title: Smooth registration
body:
Addison House has always been my family's surgery growing up, but when I moved away for university in 2016 I stopped being a permanent patient. I called today to re-register as a 'new' patient. I managed to download the registration form from the surgery's website, which is generally easy to navigate and user friendly.

Unfortunately the surgery's email address isn't published on the website or NHS page, and so I had to call reception to request this. I waited slightly longer on the phone than I would have wanted, but not an unreasonable amount of time (and understandable given the public health situation). The receptionist was very friendly and more than happy to help, this was one of the reasons I was eager to re-register with Addison House as this friendly service is what I remember growing up. Overall I was really satisfied with the patient registration process, the one think I would change is publishing the surgery email address online.

title: A Very Satisfied ‘Customer’
body: Having attended A and E at St Helier today I left feeling very well looked after - all the staff were friendly, positive, and professional and throughout there was a good team atmosphere - well done to all and thank you - Bob

title: Great Practice
body: I cannot thank this practice enough for helping me with my aunt this practice went over and above with the duty of care , such a fabulous team all round from clinicians,   Excellent management , administration  a credit to the NHS I would really recommend this practice if you are in need of a GP practice .

title: Excellent Service  - a credit
body: Visited ENT today for a follow up appointment - excellent service with advice and reassurance when  my wife and I were very concerned

readBy.name: Sherwood Forest Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great practice
body:
I have had a sister 
 in Mount Pleasant for the past 4 years.
She is really happy there, the care she has received as been exceptional. The staff have always been so kind and caring.
Always having the time to talk and make her laugh.
They have worked so hard to keep all the residents safe during the corona crisis.
All the family cannot thank them enough.

title: on time
body: doctor was there early so saw him earlier than expected, listened to me answered my questions good visit , as always .

title: Pharmacists are really helpful
body: I had a medication review with a female pharmacist. She was very pleasant and calm and was able to go through my medication properly without feeling rushed and took her time to explain everything in detail. I've never had such a detailed review done and it was very refreshing that I was able to feel reassured

title: Excellent follow up and support
body: I think this practice went really above and beyond what I would have expected in terms of follow-up. Really impressed.
